title: Paradoxically Simpson
text: Note that I used Positron as my IDE, rather than R Studio, so there are some differences.

title: Paradoxically Simpson
Paradoxically Simpson
text:
3.2 Plotting by Species


Show the code
# Use function in functions.r

p1 <- create_scatterplot(df_clean_data, "Adelie", "#6689c6") 
p2 <- create_scatterplot(df_clean_data, "Gentoo", "#e85252") 
p3 <- create_scatterplot(df_clean_data, "Chinstrap", "#9a6fb0") 
p1 + p2 + p3





There is actually a positive correlation when split by species.

datatable(df_clean_data,
  filter = "top",
)

title: Paradoxically Simpson
text:
4.2 knitr


Show the code
# Compute some result
bill_length_per_species <- df_clean_data %>% group_by(species) %>% 
  summarise(average_bill_length = mean(bill_length_mm, na.rm = TRUE))

# Display in the Quarto report
kable(bill_length_per_species)





species
average_bill_length




Adelie
38.80872


Chinstrap
48.83382


Gentoo
47.50488

title: Paradoxically Simpson
text:
4.3 Personal ggplot theme


Show the code
ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = mpg, y = wt)) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(title = "Customized Scatterplot", x = "Miles Per Gallon", y = "Weight")  +
  cmad_theme()










4.3.1 Sample latex
\[E=mc^2\]
